newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul won ends lower on central bank intervention.
newsitem.headline: Seoul won ends lower on central bank intervention.

text.p: The won closed lower against the U.S. currency after the central bank stepped into the interbank market twice on Friday, dealers said.
They said the Bank of Korea bought dollars at 891.20 before the morning close and at 892.30 in the afternoon session.
The central bank's intervention was seen as slowing the won's rise, which was sparked by the dollar's fall against the yen in world markets.
The won finished at 893.10, compared with Thursday's close of 892.90. Before the intervention, the won rose to 890.80 on the dollar's weakness versus the yen.

But a finance ministry official said it was too early to say the dollar had begun falling against the yen. He also said it was not necessary for the won/dollar rate to fluctuate in line with dollar/yen rate from a short-term point of view.
Dealers forecast the dollar would hover around the 890 won level for the time being.
Trading volume was estimated at $2.03 billion won.
Monday's mid-rate is expected to be pegged at 892.20 against 894.10 today.
